You know @ScottMorrisonMP .. I am so blessed to have a disability . Makes me great at innovating , problem solving and is at the core of who I am . I would not change it . Diversity and inclusion matters  . Your words matter . Oh and I vote. #auspol #disabilityinclusion #blessed

Woke up to find our Prime Minister, Scott Morrison, has managed to upset the world!
I deliberately missed the debate as it was on a Murdoch outlet.
I stand with people with a #Disability.
Our PM has no shame, nor wherewithal.

@CroweDM @jenkspl64 Don’t even have to read this to know how old mate is going to call it.
FFS imagine compromising yourself this hard for your overlords… 
The man literally said he was ‘blessed’ not to have a disabled child.
I do & I am indeed ‘blessed’.
What a sorry state our ‘journalism’ is in.

@_Stacey_Lee_ I can’t let this slide. Both my children are on the autism spectrum, and I wouldn’t have it any other way. Pretending to “relate” by saying he’s blessed not to have children as such, to which he referred to as “disabled” is very much off the mark, and highly offensive to many.

This is my 20th year supporting people with disability. Of course the man who looks to the sky for answers doesn’t understand how amazing these people are. And he never will. Vote him out. #blessed #auspoll2022 #auspol

(Yes I am deliberately using negative terms for ordinary people. If you don't like it, that's "disabled" people's lives)

@SammySatine He did. And as a 45 year old disabled woman - who has just been approved for NDIS funding and support - I’m deeply, deeply offended and hurt. I am/ was and will always be someone’s disabled child.
Hollie Hughes is a prime example that being the parent of a child with a disability does not a virtue make. @BreakfastNews #ausvotes

Ok here we go, Hollie Hughes wheeled out to provide cover for Morrison. Senator Hughes is mother of someone with a disability but that doesn’t mean she can excuse Morrison’s blatant ableism. @BreakfastNews #LeadersDebate #ausvotes

@abcnews 2/ this means that Scott thinks:

1) god tinkers with the genetics of children
2) "normal" kids are better than atypical ones
3) he and Jenny were chosen by God to have the allegedly better kids.
4) That the parents of the disabled kids don't have gods' blessing.

@abcnews 1/ "If I am blessed then I do not get disable children" is logically equivalent to "if I have disabled children then I am not blessed."

Most people understand this intuitively. If you don't like it, take it up with Aristotle.

All the focus on morning TV of the debate is Morrison confronting Albanese about boats. Nothing about Morrison’s horrendous ableism in responding to a mother of a disabled child. #LeadersDebate #ausvotes @BreakfastNews

To make it worse, as someone who has literally had surgery to put in a cochlear implant, NDIS still rejected me for not being eligible as a disabled person? Do they think I've had the surgery for funsies? The whole system needs a massive reform in being less of a barrier!

I guess I have to say sorry to my parents for being a burden on them as a profoundly deaf person, isn't that right Mr Morrison? What an absurd statement for a PM to make to make suggesting that disabled people are a curse instead of a blessing on your family. Ridiculous.
@Tara_Moss I guess he doesn't feel blessed to have that disabled brother in law he keeps wheeling out every time he talks about the NDIS.

Scott Morrison says during a debate (logical equivalent) that if you have disabled kids you aren't blessed and that disability (or its lack) is a product of gods approval of the parents, not genetics. 

The press seems to think that attacking people's kids will blow over.
#auspol

@politicsabc @David_Speers I think you will find that Morrison may be knocked off course by his "blessed" comment, but it will be a slow burn.

This disability community and those (like me) who have family on the spectrum know what we heard. 

He had a go at our kids and families.

#auspol

@lawrepforjesus He could come back with "blessed to have disabled children as well, it's all part of God's plan, everyone's blessed"

But that opens him up to "are you blessed to be poor" and "have you been such an advocate for opening up during Covid because death is gods plan" #auspkl
@SenatorJordon No child is a burden .. Disabled or healthy .. children are gifts .. protect them
@vanOnselenP You seriously think there won’t be outrage tomorrow from the 4.4m Australians living with a disability. You’re more naïve than I thought Peter.

But that’s all they did
They didn’t even define disability 
Zero funds were allocated

Did she/we, the disabled community get an answer to her question?

No. She was insulted. 

#auspol #ndis

Aside from being “othered” simply for being #disabled, by these sorts of statements, being on the NDIS requires attending “Reviews” where our “permanent” disabilities require reproved so as prevent our funding being slashed. EVERY TIME. 

#auspol #NDIS

Forgive my frantic retweeting of Scott Morrison’s offensive comment re being blessed for not having disabled children when the questioner was actually asking about the #NDIS
#auspol
@RMMackenzie1 This, of course, assumes that he believes the blessing causes the lack of disability - which as a believer in an omnipotent and omnipresent Christian god, he most certainly does

@RMMackenzie1 I don't think it is implying.

If you are blessed THEN you will not have disabled kids.

And 

If you have disabled kids THEN you are not blessed 

Are logically equivalent (contrapositive I believe) statements.

It's literally what he explicitly said. There is no implying
@ChaserInterns Mandatory disability training scheduled and empathy consultant’s fee added to NDIS administrative costs

@vanbadham Yep 

If you don't have disabled children then you are blessed.

Is the same ae

You are not blessed if you have disabled children 

It's the logical (contrapositive) equivalent.

In @ScottMorrisonMP’s world, a child with a disability is a curse from God. 
That’s all you need to know about him. #auspol #AusVotesDebate #Disability

@PaulBongiorno @starppael @AlboMP Also any incoming government must respect, and restore the disability patients dignity, humanity rights.
And all of the Australian constitutional law and all of the international laws too, and the UN Charter too, also the high courts judge's ruling too. https://t.co/pufDEoowXB

7/

Thank you to @lindareynoldswa, @Anne_Ruston and @billshortenmp for working with @PWDAustralia. Looking forward to working with the next Government’s Ministers, their shadows, their departments and agencies, and disability champions in the Parliament like @SenatorJordon.

6/ 

5. The Commonwealth needs to show leadership. The next Government needs to coordinate with states/territories actively and proactively. So much work needs to go into ensuring services provided by states/territories work for us, no matter where a person with disability lives

5/

4. We are a diverse community. The disability community needs time, clear communication lines and engagement mechanisms, and the resources to consult widely within community. This way, everyone with disability can be included.

4/

3. People with disability are the experts about our lives. Mistakes are bound to happen, so we need transparency and accountability. We can offer solutions that stick, but we need the info and assumptions behind Government thinking.

3/

2. Trust needs to be rebuilt. The disability community must be the driving stakeholder in all decision-making. This must including us understanding what and how any changes in laws and policies effect us, before any decisions or changes are made.

2/ 

1. Disability is not just just the NDIS. We need a mindset shift. 1 in 5 Australians have a disability, so we need a disability lens across all policy areas. Not at the end, but at the start and throughout all decision-making.
